UNITED STATES
ATOMIC ENERGY COMMISSION
WASHINGTON 25, D. C.
IN REPLY REFER TO:
ISP:CH
March 1, 1951
Mr. Richard Rider
Network Coordinator
Department of Radio
University of Illinois
Urbana, Illinois
Dear Richard Rider:
Here is the situation with regard to rebroadcasting
by non-commercial stations of the atomic energy
series "The New World of Atomic Energy," the eleven-
program series which began on WLS Friday, February 9
and is being broadcast weekly on their "School Time."
You will note from copies of the enclosed letters that
AFM has given blanket approval for re-use but that
AFRA will require specific request from prospective
users.
We are bowing out of the picture at this point and
leave further negotiations up to those interested and
the Office of Education. Gertrude Broderick says
however that thereâ€™s no reason why NAEB members have
to cone through her office so you can deal direct
with WLS and AFRA.
Of course, all of us are indebted to the original
decision of WLS to make the entire series available
for rebroadcast, subject only to union clearances
and a WLS credit.
I have not heard any of the broadcasts so far but
all reports I received indicate that it is one of
the best educational projects in the atomic energy
field that has been attempted to date. WLS is
working closely with the AEC's Argonne National
Laboratory at Chico which reviews the scripts for
technical accuracy.
